qas.question: By the thirteenth century, what had the Czech language separated from?
How long was the precursor to Czech classified as Old Czech?
How did Old Czech's use of cases differ from modern usage?

answers.text: did not yet have a vocative case or an animacy distinction

qas.question: How many cases did Old Czech have?
What other language did Old Czech's declension patterns resemble?
What other languages did Lithuanian separate from?
What was Lithuanian called by the thirteenth century?
How many cases did Lithuanian have?
How many genders were used in Lithuanian in the past?
How long was Lithuanian considered Old Czech?

context: The Czechs' language separated from <a0_0><b5_0>other Slavic tongues<b5_0/><a0_0/> into what would later be called <b6_0>Old Czech<b6_0/> by the thirteenth century, a classification extending <a1_0><b9_0>through the sixteenth century<b9_0/><a1_0/>. Its use of cases differed from the modern language; although Old Czech <a2_0>did not yet have a vocative case or an animacy distinction<a2_0/>, declension for its <a3_0><b7_0>six<b7_0/><a3_0/> cases and <b8_0>three<b8_0/> genders rapidly became complicated (partially to differentiate homophones) and its declension patterns resembled those of <a4_0>Lithuanian<a4_0/> (its Balto-Slavic cousin).
